user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleInfo:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleInfo(osal_id_t module_id, OS_module_prop_t *module_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *         record;
    OS_module_internal_record_t *module;
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_token_t            token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(module_prop);

    memset(module_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_module_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_module_table, token);
        module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, token);

        strncpy(module_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(module_prop->name) - 1);
        strncpy(module_prop->filename, module->file_name, sizeof(module_prop->filename) - 1);

        return_code = OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl(&token, module_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_module_table
...
OS_module_internal_record_t OS_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
typedef struct
{
    cpuaddr             entry_point;
    cpuaddr             host_module_id;
    char                filename[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    char                name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_module_address_t addr;
} OS_module_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char             module_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    char             file_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    OS_module_type_t module_type;
    uint32           flags;
    cpuaddr          entry_point;
} OS_module_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
int32 OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_module_prop_t *module_prop)
{
    /*
     * Limiting strictly to POSIX-defined API means there is no defined
     * method to get information about a module contents.
     *
     * The "dlinfo()" function might return some interesting information
     * but this is actually a non-posix extension / platform-defined API.
     *
     * This returns success - although there is no information to add here,
     * the parent/shared layer information is still valid.
     */
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments in the provided snippets use compiler language extensions that are commonly documented as such (for example: __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, GCC/Clang-specific keywords, or other nonstandard language constructs). The code uses only standard C constructs: typedefs (int32, uint32, osal_id_t), macros, pointer/array operations, strncpy/memset, extern declarations, and ordinary function calls. The comment in OS_ModuleGetInfo_Impl mentioning dlinfo() refers to a platform/library API (a non-POSIX extension), not a compiler language extension, so it does not trigger Rule 1.2. The BUGCHECK and OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macros as shown do not contain any obvious compiler-specific extensions; their usages (taking addresses, indexing arrays, passing tokens by address) are standard C. Therefore there are no fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2. If the project uses a compiler that treats certain standard C features as extensions (or has project-specific macros that expand to compiler-specific constructs), those expansions should be reviewed in their definitions/headers, but they are not present in the provided code.
